Tel/Fax: +86-532-84022016 Tel/Fax: +86-532-84022016 Among the sustainable energy sources, hydrogen is the one most promising for alleviating the pollution issues related to the usage of conventional fuels, as it can be produced in an efficient and eco-friendly way via electrocatalytic water splitting. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, a half-reaction of water splitting) plays a pivotal role in decreasing the price and increasing the catalytic efficiency of hydrogen production and is efficiently promoted by metal phosphides in different electrolytes. Herein, we summarize the recent advances in the development of metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts, focus on their synthesis (post-treatment, in situ generation, and electrodeposition methods) and the enhancement of their electrocatalytic activity (via elemental doping, interface and vacancy engineering, construction of specific supports and nanostructures, and the design of bi- or polymetallic phosphides), and highlight the crucial issues and challenges of future development. Graphical abstract This review summarizes the recent developments in metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts, focusing on the synthetic strategies and effective ways of boosting electrocatalytic performance. Keywords Metal phosphides Electrocatalytic reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction Synthesis strategies Hydrogen energy 1 Introduction The growing extent of the energy crisis and the environmental pollution issues related to the combustion of traditional fossil fuels necessitate the search for alternative renewable and clean energy carriers to reduce overreliance on these fuels and decrease the emission of CO2 [1–6]. To this end, various sustainable (e.g., solar, wind, ocean, and biomass) energies have been investigated, and substantial progress has been achieved in this field. However, as the widespread application of these sources is hindered by their inherent intermittence and instability, valid strategies on overcoming these issues should be developed. Hydrogen has recently attracted much attention as an energy carrier owing to its high energy density and zero carbon emission [7–10]. To date, hydrogen is mainly produced by natural gas pyrolysis and coal gasification, both of which produce CO2 as a by-product and should therefore be succeeded by more environmentally friendly strategies [11–14] such as overall electrocatalytic water splitting, which offers the benefits of remarkable catalytic efficiency and the absence of greenhouse gas emissions [15–22]. The overall electrocatalytic water splitting comprises two separate half-reactions, namely the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), with the former/latter requiring a theoretical potential of 1.23 V vs. the normal hydrogen electrode [23–25]. However, as the practical water electrolysis potential is usually far from the theoretical value owing to electrode polarization, much effort has been directed at the development of efficient electrocatalysts to resolve these issues and accelerate the reaction rate. At present, Pt and Pt-based nanomaterials are considered highly effective HER electrocatalysts with the smallest Tafel slope and a nearly zero overpotential, although the scarcity and high cost of Pt hinder their large-scale practical applications in hydrogen production [26–28]. As a result, many researchers have explored substitutes to lower the cost of electrocatalysts and promote the practical applications of hydrogen energy [29–36]. Among the developed alternatives, metal phosphides, which can be divided into transition metal phosphides (TMPs) and noble metal phosphides (NMPs), have drawn much attention due to their high intrinsic activity and have become popular HER electrocatalysts [37–41]. The synthesis of metal phosphides is relatively benign relative to that of metal carbides, nitrides, and sulfides, which have also been investigated as HER electrocatalysts. In general, P in metal phosphides has two functions, i.e., it acts as a basic site capturing protons and thus facilitating hydrogen adsorption and modifies the electron density at surrounding (especially metal) atoms via electron donation/abstraction to adjust their adsorption performance. The metal (M) in phosphides also usually has two functions, acting as an active site for hydrogen evolution and increasing the electrical conductivity of the catalyst. In metal phosphides, the electronegativity difference between M and P leads to electron transfer and results in M–P bond polarization. The basic P traps protons and neutralizes the free energy released by the adsorption of hydrogen atoms on M. Moreover, the stoichiometric M:P molar ratio can be easily altered to optimize electrocatalytic performance [42]. The rational utilization of electronegativity differences between M and P and the above molar ratio optimization allows one to obtain metal phosphide electrocatalysts with good HER performance. In 2005, Liu and co-authors [43] used theoretical calculations to demonstrate the feasibility of Ni2P as a HER electrocatalyst and showed that P directly participates in the electrochemical reaction. The first experimental study on metal phosphides was reported by Zhang et al. [44], who prepared nanoporous FeP nanosheets by an anion-exchange reaction and revealed their excellent electrocatalytic performance (low overpotential and small Tafel slope) for the HER. In addition to TMPs, NMPs have attracted much attention owing to their Pt-like or even Pt-superior activity in aqueous electrolytes within a wide pH range [45]. Mu’s group [46] synthesized N-/P-co-doped carbon-encapsulated Ru2P (Ru2P@NC) and demonstrated its excellent performance in acidic (38 mV@10 mA cm−2), neutral (57 mV@10 mA cm−2), and basic (52 mV@10 mA cm−2) electrolytes. At present, more facile, highly efficient, and time-saving strategies have been widely exploited, and numerous techniques of increasing electrocatalytic activity have been developed. Therefore, it is necessary to summarize the recent developments in metal phosphides, including TMPs and NMPs. Herein, we review the recent progress in the development of metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts, starting with the related synthetic methods (post-treatment, in situ generation, and electrodeposition), continuing with the discussion of strategies on improving electrocatalytic HER performance (Fig. 1 ), and finally discussing future challenges and perspectives. Given the large amount of available data, this review focuses on the advances of the recent three years. 2 Basic HER theory 2.1 Fundamental HER principles The HER is one of the simplest electrocatalytic reactions, involving two-electron transfer and proceeding via the Volmer-Heyrovsky or the Volmer-Tafel mechanism, depending on the reaction medium (pH) and catalyst [47]. A deep understanding of the reaction mechanism and the origin of the associated overpotential are required for the design of high-performance HER catalysts. Both of the above mechanisms involve H* as a reactive intermediate. In acidic media, the HER proceeds as follows: Volmer reaction: H+ + e − → H* Tafel reaction: H* + H* → H2 Heyrovsky reaction: H* + H+ + e − → H2 In alkaline solution, molecular water is thought to be involved: Volmer reaction: H2O + e − → H* + OH− Heyrovsky reaction: H* + H2O + e − → H2 + OH− Perfect HER catalysts should exhibit both high activity and good stability, with the best currently available catalysts corresponding to Pt and Pt-group metals [48]. At present, non-noble-metal catalysts with low cost and excellent performance are highly sought after. In recent years, metal phosphides, especially TMPs, have received increasing attention because of their low cost, excellent HER activity, and high stability [132]. Cai et al. [116] obtained a highly efficient P-rich TMP catalyst by modulating the nonpolar P–P interaction to tailor the overlap of atomic wave functions. 2.2 Metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts TMPs and NMPs can be considered as P-doped metal lattices, with the results of electrochemical tests and theoretical calculations indicating the importance of P for HER activity. For example, the optimal ΔG H* of NiSe2-Ni2P/NF approaches the ideal value of 0 eV (cf. NiSe2 (0.8 eV) and Ni2P (−0.31 eV)), which demonstrates that the presence of doped P and the thus generated interfaces can improve HER performance through the optimization of hydrogen adsorption energy [161]. Various structures have different advantages, and different synthetic strategies can be used to obtain phosphides with different nanostructures such as nanoflowers [47,48], hollow structures [49,50], nanoarrays [51,52], nanorods [53,54], etc. [55–57]. In addition, compared to normal catalysts, metal phosphides offer the benefits of facile synthesis, high efficiency, and cost/time saving. By rationally utilizing the M-P electronegativity difference and optimizing the M:P ratio, one can obtain electrocatalysts with excellent HER performance. Among the disadvantages of metal phosphides as HER catalysts, one should mention their relatively complicated synthesis and the fact that with increasing extent of P doping, the catalysts become semiconductors or even insulators because of the adverse effect of electronegative P atoms on electron delocalization. For instance, FeP exhibits metallic characteristics with a density of states (DOS) around the Fermi level, while the values for Mg-FeP and Vc-FeP are slightly lower than that of FeP, indicating a decrease in electrical conductivity [202]. However, TMPs (especially metal-rich ones) can be engineered to show metallic or even superconductive properties via M:P ratio adjustment. To obtain HER catalysts with excellent performance and good stability, one should consider some factors in phosphide electrocatalyst design, e.g., the moderation of bonding to intermediates [113,132], maximization of catalytic site exposure [68], and satisfactory electrical conductivity [202]. In summary, the strategies on synthesizing metal phosphides and improving their HER performance have important reference significance for future research. 3 Synthesis of metal phosphides Synthetic strategies play a pivotal role in regulating nanomaterial morphology, phase composition, and particle size, which allows for electrocatalytic performance optimization. With the development of nanotechnologies, various eco- friendly, low-cost, and large-scale production-suitable strategies of metal phosphide synthesis have been exploited. Herein, we classify these approaches into those based on post-treatment, in situ generation, and electrodeposition (Fig. 2 ). 3.1 Post-treatment methods Post-treatment methods are popular strategies of synthesizing metal phosphides with various morphologies, allowing one to expose abundant active sites and favor electrolyte transportation. Among the applied P sources, hypophosphites such as NaH2PO2 are widely used to release PH3 upon heating to 250 °C and can therefore act as substitutes for the toxic PH3 gas. However, the pyrolysis of hypophosphites still generates excessive PH3. In view of the above, phosphates have been extensively investigated as low-toxicity materials for metal phosphide synthesis, which generally requires high temperatures to break P–O bonds. Previously, we synthesized Mo phosphides supported by different carbon matrices and demonstrated the high HER performances of these catalysts [58,59]. However, the related synthesis is usually performed at high temperatures and is therefore energy-consuming and prone to induce the clumping of nanoparticles into irregular aggregates, which limits the number of exposed active sites for the electrocatalytic process. Therefore, more moderate ways of preparing metal phosphides from low-toxic phosphates are needed. 3.2 In situ generation methods Metal phosphides can also be obtained by in situ generation methods from P-containing precursors such as phytic acid, melamine phosphate, saccharomycetes, tri-n-octylphosphine, and triphenylphosphine. This approach allows one to simplify the preparation procedure and form a heteroatom-doped carbon matrix or shell to enhance catalyst performance and stability. Organic P is one of the most popular sources for metal phosphide formation and is typically used in the solution phase at high temperatures, e.g., Schaak’s group synthesized metal phosphides with remarkable electrocatalytic performances from organic P [60–63]. The phases and morphologies of the thus prepared catalysts can be adjusted by tuning parameters such as temperature, solvent type, and reaction time to optimize electrocatalytic activity [42,64–67]. However, the large-scale application of organic P precursors is hindered by their toxicity and flammability. Moreover, these precursors should be handled under oxygen-free conditions, which results in extra costs, while the blocking of the active sites of metal phosphides by residual ligands negatively affects electrocatalytic activity [68]. Non-toxic P-containing precursors have been extensively investigated for the synthesis of metal phosphides in combination with heteroatom-doped carbon materials [69]. The in situ generated carbon matrix can not only decrease electrical resistance, but also help to avoid the aggregation of nanoparticles. Among the numerous P precursors, phytic acid has been often used to prepare metal phosphides owing to six phosphoryl groups within its structure [70–72]. Moreover, the interactions between metal ions and P decrease the nanoparticle size and benefit electrocatalytic activity. Apart from phytic acid, Zhou and co-authors [73–75] used saccharomycetes as a cheap, green, and abundant raw material to prepare metal phosphides, showing that the obtained nanomaterials exhibited high electrocatalytic performance. 3.3 Electrodeposition methods The post-treatment and in situ generation methods suffer from high energy consumption, toxic gas release, and time-consuming procedures. Therefore, ways of circumventing these problems are highly sought after. Unlike the above two methods, electrodeposition can be carried out at room temperature and offers the benefits of simplicity, low energy consumption, eco-friendliness, and excellent adhesion to the electrode substrate [76–82]. Zhang and co-authors [83] used electrodeposition to prepare Ni-Cu-P catalysts with a pine-needle-like dendrite nanotube morphology, with the branch nanotubes growing on the trunk and the smaller branches growing on larger branches. However, the required synthetic materials are generally amorphous and offer a limited morphology choice, which hinders the improvement of electrocatalytic performance. Despite this disadvantage, electrodeposition holds great promise for metal phosphide synthesis, and more attention should be paid to the optimization of nanostructure, composition, phase, etc. Different synthetic strategies and comparison of metal phosphide electrocatalysts are summarized in Table 1 . 4 Strategies on improving electrocatalytic performance Despite the advances in the development of metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts, their performance is still far from satisfying the practical needs of hydrogen production and should therefore be improved. Given that HER activity is correlated with many factors such as the electroconductivity, quantity of exposed active sites, and electronic structure, various methods of increasing this activity (e.g., elemental doping, interface and vacancy engineering, use of specific supports and structures) have been adopted (Fig. 3 ). 4.1 Elemental doping Elemental doping has attracted much attention as a means of optimizing electrocatalytic performance for energy-related reactions [101–106]. The doping of metal phosphides with metals does not afford new phases but can result in lattice expansion and electronic structure changes. According to the type of dopant, elemental doping can be divided into metal doping, non-metal doping, and metal + non-metal co-doping. Previous reports [107–110] have shown that doping allows one to adjust the electrocatalytic activities of metal phosphides by tuning the electronic structure, coordination nature, binding energy, etc. without changing the original material and enables the optimization of active sites and the adsorption energy of intermediates. In addition, elemental doping can also generate new active sites and synergize with host substances to further improve HER activity. Among the heteroatom-doped materials, sulfur-doped nanomaterials have been widely investigated for catalytic activity optimization. Ma and co-authors obtained sulfur-doped NiCoP nanowire arrays on carbon fiber paper (S-NiCoP/CFP) via sulfuration and phosphorization [111] and revealed that this electrocatalyst exhibited high HER activity (172 mV@100 mA cm−2) in 1 M KOH. For ideal HER electrocatalysts, the Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption (ΔG H*) should be close to zero, i.e., the electrocatalysts should easily adsorb and desorb H* to allow the rapid evolution of H2 [112], whereas the overly strong adsorption of intermediates at metal sites hinders the re-adsorption of reactants. The replacement of P with S in NiCoP weakened the adsorption of intermediates (such as H2O*, OH*, and H*) and induced an increase in ΔG H* from −0.47 to 0.11 eV (Fig. 4(a) ), i.e., decreased the electron density around the metal and thus promoted the desorption of H* to enhance catalytic activity. Chen et al. developed a controllable surface layer–confined doping strategy to engineer the chemical composition and morphology of CoP nanowire arrays (S-CoP) based on an ion-exchange mechanism. The electrocatalyst was prepared by a sequence of hydrothermal, ion-exchange, and phosphorization steps (Fig. 4(b)), and the thickness of the surficial amorphous layer could be altered by changing the duration of the exposition to the Na2S solution and its concentration. S-CoP required a small overpotential of 104 mV to drive a current density of 100 mA cm−2 and exhibited high long-term stability. The free energy of H adsorption on CoP (002) and (101) increased to −0.22 and −0.28 eV, respectively, after the replacement of P with S and further increased to −0.21 and −0.22 eV, respectively, after P-vacancy introduction (S-CoP; Fig. 4(c)). The above values signified weak H atom adsorption and indicated that Co atoms that coordinated with the doped S or were adjacent to P vacancies on the surface improved HER performance. Fig. 4(d) shows the calculated d-orbital partial DOS of Co in CoP, CoP-S1, and S-CoP, revealing that the distance between the d-band center and the Fermi level follows the order of CoP < CoP-S1 < S-CoP. Based on the d-band theory, a lower-lying d-band center results in the weak adsorption of H on the catalyst surface. In addition, electron density difference calculations for the Co–H bonding region of H adsorbed on the (002) surface of CoP, CoP-S1, and S-CoP indicated that the electron density follows the order of CoP > CoP-S1 > S-CoP (Fig. 4(e)). These studies show the synergistic effect of S dopants and P vacancies on weakening the interaction between the adsorbed H and Co [113]. In addition to S doping, N doping has also been used to optimize the catalytic performance of metal phosphides [114,115]. For example, Song and co-authors [116] demonstrated that N doping induced the lattice contraction and boosted the HER activities of P-rich TMPs such as CoP2, FeP2, NiP2, and MoP2. The developed N-CoP2 exhibited remarkable HER performance in 0.5 M H2SO4 (38 mV@10 mA cm−2, Tafel slope = 46 mV dec−1). Fig. 4(f) presents the crystal structures and lattice constants of CoP2 and N-CoP2, revealing that these constants decreased after the incorporation of N and demonstrating the concomitant lattice contraction due to the formation of shorter and stronger N–P bonds in N-CoP2. The strong N–P interaction increased the atomic wave function overlap and eventually regulated the H adsorption strength to decrease ΔG H* and thus increase HER activity. Gao et al. [117] used N2 plasma to synthesize N-doped MoP on carbon cloth (N-MoP/CC), obtaining excellent catalytic activity in 1 M KOH. Experimental and theoretical results showed that the doping of N into MoP resulted in Mo-P species enrichment and promoted electron localization near doped sites to enhance electrocatalytic activity. Dual zerovalent non-metal (N and B)-doped Ni2P nanoparticles strongly coupled with graphene (N,B-Ni2P/G) were prepared by pyrolysis of Ni-Bi/graphene in the presence of NH3 and NaH2PO2 and exhibited high HER performance over a wide pH range [118]. As illustrated in Fig. 4(g), N,B-Ni2P/G featured a lower overpotential of 124 mV@10 mA cm−2 than Ni2P (221 mV), B-Ni2P (198 mV), N-Ni2P (190 mV), N,B-Ni2P (168 mV), and B-Ni2P/G (139 mV) in 1 M PBS, i.e., co-doping with two different heteroatoms effectively improved electrocatalytic performance. DFT calculations revealed that heteroatom doping can effectively optimize water and hydrogen adsorption energies and improve catalytic activity. Apart from heteroatom doping, metal doping is also an efficient way of enhancing electrocatalytic activity through the optimization of the electronic structure or the regulation of adsorption free energy [119–131]. Lou and co-authors [132] prepared uniform hollow nanorods of Ni-doped FeP nanocrystals hybridized with carbon as HER catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the above electrocatalyst was prepared by annealing using MIL-88A as a precursor and phytic acid as an etchant and a P source. The as-prepared Ni-doped MIL-88A contained highly uniform hexagonal rod-like solid nanostructures. After treatment with phytic acid solution, Ni-doped MIL-88A retained the overall rod-like appearance and was etched out to generate hollow nanostructures with increased specific surface area and more available space. The resulting electrocatalyst exhibited remarkable HER activity, showing overpotentials of 72, 117, and 95 mV@10 mA cm−2 in acidic, neutral, and alkaline media, respectively. The lowest hydrogen coverage extent (θ H) was correlated with the coverage at which HER occurs. Moreover, the ΔG H* of Pt and Ni-doped FeP exhibited only small changes within a moderate range regardless of the alteration of θ H. The fact that ΔG H* was close to zero for the latter also indicated good HER performance compared with that of FeP, in which case ΔG H* became very low as θ H decreased to <50%, which indicated strong bonding between the adsorbed hydrogen and the catalyst (Fig. 5(b)). Thus, the experimental results demonstrated that Ni doping can increase the active content of metal phosphides. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that both electronic density and ΔG H* can be optimized by doping FeP with Ni. The integration of a specific nanostructure and reaction process regulation endowed the obtained nanomaterials with remarkable catalytic activity. Metal phosphides doped with other transition metals such as V, W, Co, and Mo were also investigated and presented remarkable HER activities [133–136]. Luo and co-authors [137] established a design principle to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of TMPs in alkaline media by tuning the proportion of the unoccupied 3d orbitals (P un) of the doped transition metals. The P un of the Co metal center in CoP implies that only a small fraction of the unoccupied 3d orbitals of Co can accommodate the lone pair electrons of the water HOMO (Fig. 5(c)). In addition, strong Pauli repulsion exists between a large fraction of Co metal center electrons and the lone pair electrons of water. Thus, as shown in Fig. 5(d), the introduction of transition metal centers (M’) with higher P un into CoP adds more unoccupied 3d orbitals to accommodate the lone pair electrons of the water HOMO and thus leads to a strong interaction between M’ and water to destabilize the H–OH bond. DFT calculations demonstrated that Cr atoms with a higher value of P un not only favor water adsorption and activation, but also modulate the electronic structure of CoP and locate the d-band center of atoms away from the Fermi level to afford an optimal H binding strength. The P un of doped transition metals followed the order of PV un > PCr(Mo) un > PMn un > PFe un > PCo un > Pun Ni > Pun Cu, which resulted in the following order of electrocatalytic performance in alkaline media: V-CoP > Cr (Mo)-CoP > Mn-CoP > Fe-CoP > CoP > Ni-CoP > Cu-CoP (Figs. 5(e)–(g)). Moreover, the authors also demonstrated that the sluggish reaction kinetics in alkaline media is due to water adsorption and dissociation energies and not to H adsorption strength. In addition to transition metal doping, the noble metal doping of metal phosphides has been studied as a means of electrocatalytic performance enhancement [138]. Song and co-authors [139] synthesized Ni5P4 doped with single Ru atoms as a HER catalyst. Ni(OH)2 with Ni vacancies (V-Ni(OH)2) was first prepared using a propylene oxide-mediated alkalization precipitation strategy, with the generated cationic vacancies acting as anchors to stabilize Ru3+ during impregnation. The target catalyst was obtained by phosphorization in the presence of NaH2PO2 and presented remarkable HER performance (54 mV@ 10 mA cm−2, 52 mV dec−1, Table 2 ). DFT results demonstrated that the introduction of single-atomic Ru led to localized structural polarization and optimized the H2O dissociation process. Thus, heteroatom and metal atom doping can be used to optimize electrocatalytic HER performance by tuning of reaction free energy and intermediate adsorption/desorption. 4.2 Interface engineering Interface engineering, which can be performed by introducing two or more different heteroatoms into monometallic compounds or by combining two or more different metal compounds, allows one to modify the physicochemical properties of catalysts as well as to tune their performance and selectivity [152–156]. The interfaces created in electrocatalysts can affect the adsorption/desorption of intermediates as well as the transportation of electrons and adsorbates during the electrocatalytic process to enhance the sluggish HER [157–160]. Thus, much effort has been directed at the introduction of interfaces into metal phosphides to optimize their catalytic activity and stability. The introduction of two or more heteroatoms into monometallic compounds is a valid strategy for creating interfaces. Mu et al. [161] synthesized NiSe2 and Ni2P coupled nanowrinkles on Ni foam (NiSe2-Ni2P/NF) via the three steps of hydrothermal treatment, selenization, and phosphorization, revealing that NiSe2-Ni2P/NF exhibited better HER performance (102 mV@10 mA cm−2) than Ni2P/NF (191 mV) and NiSe2/NF (201 mV) in 1 M KOH. DFT calculations were performed to shed further light on the effects of interfaces on electrocatalytic activity. As illustrated in Fig. 6(a) , NiSe2-Ni2P/NF exhibited an optimal ΔG H* of 0.01 eV, while higher values were observed for NiSe2 (0.8 eV) and Ni2P (−0.31 eV). Thus, the generated interfaces allowed one to effectively optimize the hydrogen adsorption energy. Moreover, NiSe2-Ni2P/NF had a smaller H2O adsorption energy (ΔH2O = −0.35 eV) than NiSe2 (−0.2 eV) and Ni2P (−0.25 eV) (Fig. 6(b)), i.e., H2O molecules were more easily adsorbed on hybrids with interfaces. Consequently, it was concluded that the optimal hydrogen adsorption energy and favorable H2O adsorption process endowed the designed nanomaterial with excellent catalytic activity. The same phenomenon was also observed by Li et al. [162], who synthesized Ni2P-NiSe2 on carbon cloth and showed that strong electronic interactions optimized the adsorption/desorption of intermediates. As an element belonging to the same group as S and Se, Te was also used to create interfaces in Ni2P (Ni2P/NiTe2) and enhance its HER performance. Both experimental and theoretical results demonstrated that the created interfaces provide abundant exposed active sites and enhance H* adsorption by favoring the transfer of electrons from Ni atoms to H* [163]. In addition to Ni-based electrocatalysts, Mo-containing nanomaterials have also been studied. Fu and co-authors [164] developed 2D MoP/MoS2 heterostructures on carbon cloth with abundant interfaces and showed that these catalysts exhibited excellent HER performance over a wide pH range (96, 54, and 69 mV@10 mA cm−2 in neutral, alkaline, and acidic solutions, respectively). Fu et al. [165] constructed 2D porous MoP/Mo2N (P-MoP/Mo2N) heterojunction nanosheets by pyrolysis of [PMo12O40]3−-melamine (PMo12-MA) nanosheets with the assistance of polyethylene glycol. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that the added polyethylene glycol engages in hydrogen bonding with MA and can modulate its coordination to polyoxometalates to form a 2D nanostructure. As shown in Fig. 6(c), P-MoP/Mo2N contained numerous holes produced by the decomposition of MA units. Moreover, MoP and Mo2N were observed (featuring crystal planes of 0.21 and 0.24 nm) and formed heterointerfaces, which possibly induced electron redistribution and thus regulated catalytic activity. The obtained P-MoP/Mo2N exhibited excellent HER activity, featuring overpotentials of 89, 91, and 89 mV@10 mA cm−2 in alkaline, neutral, and acidic media, respectively. DFT calculations carried out to clarify the remarkable catalytic performance of the prepared electrocatalysts demonstrated that compared with MoP and Mo2N, the heterointerface-containing catalyst exhibited the lowest adsorption energy of H* and favorable H2O adsorption energies, which enhanced HER performance in acidic, basic, and neutral electrolytes. The observed localized states showed that heterointerfaces can enhance electron mobility during the HER process. In addition, the calculated work functions of P-MoP-Mo2N were close to that of Pt/C, indicating a strong ability to capture electrons and thus help reduce H* to H2 and enhance HER activity. Interfaces in monometallic phosphides with different phases can also optimize electrocatalytic performance. Chen et al. [166] synthesized hierarchical porous Ni12P5-Ni2P polymorphs on Ni foam via coarsening, hydrothermal treatment, and phosphorization (Fig. 6(d)). Coarsening produced a multistage pore structure that provided abundant nucleation sites for the growth of Ni(OH)2 followed by the initial heterogeneous nucleation of active Ni(OH)2 nucleation sites and the growth of Ni(OH)2 from the initial nuclei. Finally, the overall hierarchically porous morphology of Ni-P/Ni/NF was obtained by thermal phosphorization. DFT calculations demonstrated that the enhanced electrocatalytic performance may be ascribed to the interfaces of Ni12P5 and Ni2P, which exhibited optimal ΔG H*. Furthermore, the specific porous nanostructure featured abundant exposed active sites and favored mass transport during the electrocatalytic process. The prepared electrocatalyst exhibited excellent HER performance in alkaline, acidic, and neutral electrolytes (129, 83, and 112 mV@10 mA cm−2, respectively). Apart from the introduction of heteroatoms to form interfaces, the combination of different metals can also be used to construct interfaces in nanomaterials. Sun et al. [167–169] synthesized electrocatalysts with interfaces by coupling metal phosphides (Ni2P, CoP, and Cu3P) with CeO2. Theoretical and experimental results demonstrated that the developed hybrids exhibited remarkable HER activity, as the formed interfaces promoted water splitting and optimized ΔG H*. Song et al. [170] investigated the effects of coupling CoP with MoO2, achieving superior HER activities in both acidic and alkaline media. DFT calculations demonstrated that the redistribution of charge at the interface provided optimal hydrogen adsorption ability at adjacent P sites and significantly improved HER activity. In addition to those between metal oxides and metal phosphides, interfaces between two or more metal phosphides can also be created to improve catalytic activity. For example, CoP3/Ni2P exhibited better HER performance than pure CoP3 and Ni2P [171]. DFT calculations revealed that strong interactions at interfaces can regulate the electronic environment around the active sites, resulting in optimal ΔG H*. S several electrocatalysts were constructed on the basis of CoMoP with Co x P to form abundant interfaces and thus optimize electrocatalytic performance [172,173]. Cheng et al. [174] prepared CoP nanowires coupled to defective CoMoP nanosheets on Ni foam (CoP/CoMoP) with interfaces via hydrothermal processing, ion exchange, and phosphidation (Fig. 7(a) ). The thus obtained CoP/CoMoP showed remarkable HER performance in alkaline media (34 mV@10 mA cm−2 and 94 mV@100 mA cm−2). The corresponding DFT results demonstrated that the formed interface plays a significant role in improving electrocatalytic performance, with the H2O molecules tending to dissociate on CoMoP and H tending to adsorb on CoP. The interface formed between CoP and NiCoP was also shown to play a pivotal role in improving electrocatalytic performance [175,176]. Lee et al. [177] predicted that the electronic structure and localized charge density at the NiP2-FeP2 heterointerface can be significantly regulated via coupling with metallic Cu to optimize the proton adsorption energy and lower the energy barrier for water dissociation. As shown in Fig. 7(b), activity followed the order of Cuf < NiP2-FeP2/CFP < 20 wt% Pt/C/Cuf < NiP2-FeP2/CuNW/Cuf, i.e., NiP2-FeP2/CuNW exhibited outstanding HER performance (23.6, 323, and 357 mV@10, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2, respectively) because of the synergistic effect between metallic Cu and the interface-rich NiP2-FeP2. Apart from the abovementioned interfaces, Ma et al. [178] created multiple interfaces between Ru nanoclusters and porous Ni2P using a combination of hydrothermal treatment, phosphorization, and electrodeposition (the corresponding HR-TEM image is shown in Fig. 7(c) (dashed line)) to promote the chemisorption of intermediates and thus enhance HER activity. The designed electrocatalyst presented excellent HER performance (45 mV@10 mA cm−2) superior to that of reference samples and comparable to that of a commercial Pt electrode (Fig. 7(d), Table 3 ). DFT calculations revealed that the interfaces between Ni2P and Ru favor the dissociation of water molecules and accelerate the reaction kinetics. As discussed above, the interfaces generated in electrocatalysts play a significant role in promoting their performance by tuning the reaction kinetics or optimizing the reaction pathway. 4.3 Vacancy engineering Vacancies, a type of defect, exist in most nanomaterials because of their imperfect atomic arrangement. The introduction of vacancies into electrocatalysts is an efficient way of enhancing their activities for various energy-related applications [183–187]. Experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that vacancy formation allows one to tune the electronic structure, regulate active sites, and improve electrical conductivity and thus enhance catalytic performance [188–193]. In addition, defects in electrocatalysts can also be optimized to enhance their activity. Ionic vacancies can be divided into cationic and anionic ones, both of which cause changes in the valence of elements and often regulate catalytic activity. Various anionic vacancies have been investigated to improve the activity of electrocatalysts. Qiao and co-authors [194] created Ni/Ni12P5 with (v-Ni12P5) and without (p-Ni12P5) P vacancies by changing the amount of NaH2PO2·H2O used during annealing. Electrochemical measurements demonstrated that v-Ni12P5 exhibited remarkable HER performance (27.7 mV@10 mA cm−2, 30.88 mV dec−1). As shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b) , the generated P vacancies induced electron redistribution in nickel phosphide crystals, i.e., the area of Ni 3d and P 2p overlap was depleted in electrons, while individual Ni and P atoms were enriched in electrons. The altered electronic structure may play a pivotal role in promoting electrocatalytic performance by regulating the adsorption/desorption of intermediates during the HER. Further calculations proved that the elevated electron densities at both Ni and P atoms due to P vacancy formation can reduce the limiting potential of the alkaline HER and endow the prepared electrocatalyst with remarkable activity. As reported by Qi and co-authors [195], P vacancies can enhance the doping effects of V in NiCoP synthesized by plasma engineering. Electrocatalysts treated with Ar plasma (Ar-NiCoP) and Ar plasma/V doping (Ar-NiCoP|V) exhibited a more intense electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signal at g ≈ 2.005 than NiCoP, which indicated the existence of vacancies after plasma treatment and V doping. The production of P vacancies by Ar plasma–induced etching can lead to the formation of a defective state of Ar-NiCoP. The EPR signal of Ar-NiCoP|V was slightly less intense than that of Ar-NiCoP because of the extra lattice distortions caused by cation doping. These lattice vacancies might introduce extra active sites and thus favor electrocatalytic processes. Follow-up studies revealed that P vacancies can affect the reaction between electrons and optimize the electron transfer rate to improve catalytic activity (Fig. 8(c)). Figs. 8(d) and (e) show that Ar-NiCoP|V possessed high HER activity (58 mV@10 mA cm−2) that exceeded that of its counterparts and was comparable to that of Pt/C at high current densities. In addition, Ar-NiCoP|V exhibited excellent OER performance (246 mV@10 mA cm−2). The above results indicate the positive effects of V doping and P vacancies. Moreover, Ar-NiCoP|V exhibited a slightly more intense EPR signal than Ar-NiCoP, which was ascribed to the V doping-induced formation of lattice vacancies. The former electrocatalyst exhibited excellent HER performance (58 mV@10 mA cm−2, Table 4 ). Nonmetal doping and the existence of P vacancies have also been studied to optimize the catalytic performance of metal phosphides [196,197]. Cationic vacancies can also promote electrocatalytic performance but have been less studied than anionic vacancies because of the higher formation energy of the former [198–201]. Messinger and co-authors [202] created Fe vacancies by chemical leaching of Mg as a sacrificial dopant (Vc-FeP). After the formation of Fe vacancies, ΔG H decreased from +0.16 to +0.02 eV (Fig. 8(f)), indicating a low activation barrier for the HER. Moreover, both Mg doping and vacancy introduction could optimize HER kinetics and thus enhance catalytic activity. Nonetheless, doping and vacancy defects are also associated with a reduction in electrical conductivity (Fig. 8(g)). For example, whereas FeP exhibited metallic characteristics with a DOS around the Fermi level, the DOSs of Mg-FeP and Vc-FeP around the Fermi level were slightly lower than that of FeP, which indicated a decrease in electrical conductivity. This can be seen as a drawback of doping and vacancy introduction. Upon the introduction of Fe vacancies, the Fe–P bond length in Mg-FeP and Vc-FeP decreased from 2.34 to 2.32 and 2.30 Å, respectively, which increased the overlap of Fe and P orbitals and stabilized surface-adsorbed hydrogen. Moreover, the created Fe vacancies in Vc-FeP yielded an environment more rich in P than that of FeP and Mg-FeP, which favored proton trapping and enhanced HER kinetics. Vc-FeP exhibited higher HER performance (108 mV@10 mA cm−2) than FeP (192 mV@10 mA cm−2). Similarly, W vacancies were shown to enhance the HER activity of WP [203]. As discussed above, both anionic and cationic vacancies in electrocatalysts play a significant role in promoting their HER activity. Nevertheless, research on cationic vacancies is scarce, and more types of cationic vacancies should be studied in the future. 4.4 Use of specific supports In general, specific supports exhibit poor HER performance but can considerably enhance that of the supported active nanomaterials owing to strong interactions and specific morphologies. Moreover, specific supports can improve the conductivity of catalysts and eliminate some of their original semiconductor properties. Hence, the deposition of metal phosphides on specific supports is a promising means of HER performance enhancement [153]. The supporting structure can strengthen the interaction between the main catalyst and the support and prevent the shedding of the catalyst active centers during the HER process. Among the investigated strategies, one should mention the synthesis of carbon/metal phosphide composites. In particular, heteroatom-doped carbon is most often used to support metal phosphides and optimize their catalytic activities [206–211]. Chen and co-authors [212] prepared CoP nanoparticle/defective graphene hybrids (CoP@DrGO) by a simple two-step process including H2O2 treatment and phosphorization, showing that CoP@DrGO exhibited HER activity (36.6 mV@ 10 mA cm−2, 43.1 mV dec−1) superior to those of CoP@rGO (170 mV@10 mA cm−2, 61.72 mV dec−1) and CoP (211 mV@10 mA cm−2, 72.12 mV dec−1) and thus indicating the pivotal role of defective rGO in promoting catalytic performance. DFT calculations demonstrated that CoP@DrGO possessed the best ΔG H* among the investigated systems and thus confirmed its high HER performance, in line with the experimental results (Fig. 9(a) ). Bader charge analysis further revealed that the P atoms of CoP@DrGO transferred more electrons to the H atoms than those of CoP@rGO, which facilitated the rapid transformation of P–Hads to H2 on P atoms (Figs. 9(b) and (c)). Overall, the defects in DrGO were beneficial for the nucleation of small CoP nanoparticles and the exposure of abundant active sites. Moreover, the support provided a large specific surface area and excellent electroconductivity. The defects in rGO-polarized CoP nanoparticles promoted the migration of electrons from Co to P, favoring the adsorption and desorption of H. Thus, the coupling between CoP nanoparticles and DrGO played a pivotal role in catalytic performance enhancement. Liu et al. [213] fabricated MoP nanoparticles encapsulated in N-doped carbon (MoP@NC) hollow microspheres via a template-free strategy using inorganic-organic hybrids as precursors. SEM and TEM imaging verified the presence of hollow microspheres with a diameter of 500 nm (Figs. 9(d) and (e)). As shown in Figs. 9(f) and (g), MoP-graphene with graphitic N (MoP-Gr-graphitic N) exhibited the smallest ΔE H2O* (−0.47 eV) relative to the reference samples, which indicated the favorable adsorption of H2O molecules. Meanwhile, the OH* adsorption energy (ΔE OH*) for pyridinic N (−1.74 eV) exceeded that observed for MoP (−4.72 eV), which demonstrated the favorable desorption of OH* and the provision of adequate active sites for the re-adsorption of H2O molecules. Moreover, MoP-Gr-pyridinic-N exhibited an optimal ΔG H* of −0.24 eV compared with MoP-Gr-pyrrolic-N (−0.32 eV) and MoP-Gr-graphitic-N (0.94 eV), i.e., the interactions between MoP and pyridinic N could tune the electronic structure and H* binding energy to promote catalytic activity. Benefiting from the specific hollow structure and the coupling between NC and MoP, the designed electrocatalyst exhibited excellent HER performance (96 mV@10 mA cm−2, 53 mV dec−1). However, Chen et al. [214] found that the synergistic interactions between pyridinic N and MoP increased the electron density on the N-doped support, lowered the d-band center of Mo, and weakened the Mo–H bonds, while pyridinic N hindered the strong adsorption of OH. The authors believe that the pyridinic-N-MoP sites are the ones responsible for HER activity. Moreover, the nanostructure of the carbon matrix also plays a pivotal role in regulating the electrocatalytic performance of metal phosphides [215]. Wu et al. [216] deposited CoP nanoparticles on a porous array with carbon nanotube modification using carbon fiber cloth (CFC) as a matrix (CFC-CNT-CoO x /CoP). As illustrated in Fig. 9(h), CFC was annealed in air (to form hydroxyl groups and thus impart hydrophilicity), soaked in a solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O to absorb Co2+ on the surface, and heated in the presence of a carbon source to form carbon nanotubes (CFC-CNT-CoO x ). CFC-CNT-CoO x was then soaked in an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 2-methylimidazole to form CFC-CNT-CoO x /MOF. Then, CFC-CNT-CoO x /MOF was annealed at a low temperature in air to maintain the original nanostructure (CFC-CNT-CoO x /Co3O4), and CFC-CNT-CoO x /Co3O4 was phosphorized at a low temperature to obtain CFC-CNT-CoO x /CoP. The resulting electrocatalyst featured several advantages, such as the carbon nanotubes liberating the shaded active sites and promoting the generation of new active sites, while the intimate contact between CFC and CNT-CoO x /CoP favored electron transfer, and the CoP nanoparticles exposed abundant active sites and pores on the carbon shell to promote electrolyte permeation. The above advantages were reflected in excellent HER performance (108 mV@10 mA cm−2, 60 mV dec−1). Thus, the deposition of metal phosphides on specific heteroatom-doped carbon materials is a promising means of promoting HER performance owing to the beneficial effects of electronic or bonding interactions on reaction kinetics. Several novel supports have been explored to optimize the catalytic activities of metal phosphides [217]. Shen and co-authors [218] supported ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets on hollow CoP heterostructures using ZIF-67 as a self-engaged template. As shown in Fig. 10(a) , the leaf-like ZIF-67 was synthesized first, while the Co2+ cations flowed out from the core during the hydrothermal process and then reacted with molybdate and hydroxide anions to form insoluble CoMoO4 and Co(OH)2 with leaf-like morphology. The obtained electrocatalyst achieved featured overpotentials of 53 and 77 mV@10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline media, respectively. Yan et al. [219] synthesized TMP (CoP, Ni2P, FeP, Cu3P) nanoarrays on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets via topotactic transformations from layered double hydroxides. MXenes, as a new type of 2D nanomaterials based on transition metal carbides or nitrides, have attracted much attention in energy-related fields because of their excellent electrical and metallic conductivities, surface hydrophilicity, high mechanical stability, and easily tunable nanostructure [220–224]. The strong interactions between metal phosphides and MXenes resulted in high HER performance at all pH. As shown in Figs. 10(b)–(d), the Ti3C2 MXene exhibited negligible catalytic activity in alkaline, acidic, and neutral electrolytes. Among the tested materials, CoP/Ti3C2 MXene exhibited the best HER performance (second only to that of Pt/C), featuring overpotentials of 148, 71, and 124 mV@10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, 0.5 M H2SO4, and 1 M PBS, respectively, while the respective values of MXene-free CoP equaled 209, 142, and 252 mV, and values of 148, 97, and 182 mV were obtained for a CoP + MXene physical mixture. The supported metal phosphides can be deeply investigated and explored to further enhance electrocatalytic performance. Ding et al. [225] designed a ternary heterostructure comprising CoP, N-doped carbon (CN), and Ni nanoparticles (CoP/CN/Ni). The electronic structure of CoP nanoparticles was modulated by the Ni core via the CN layer, and the Fermi level shifted to higher values after receiving electrons. As a result, the binding energy and Gibbs free energy for the reaction intermediates were optimized. The increased electron density in the vicinity of CoP hindered its surface oxidation and favored proton-electron transfer during the HER. As shown in Figs. 10(e) and (f), the oxidation/reduction peak (CoII/CoIII) of CoP/CN/Ni (0.2 mA) was less intense than that of CoP/C (0.28 mA) and was positively shifted by 21 mV, in line with the abovementioned effect of electron enrichment on surface oxidation. Moreover, the reduction potential of adsorbed oxide species was more positive for CoP/CN/Ni than for CoP/C, which demonstrated that the oxide species on CoP/CN/Ni could be sufficiently reduced to favor the HER process. CoP/CN/Ni exhibited better HER performance (106 mV@10 mA cm−2) than the reference samples in alkaline media. Table 5 Comparison of metal phosphide electrocatalysts with different supports. Therefore, the construction of specific nanostructures is an effective means of enhancing the HER performance of metal phosphides. Highly hydrophilic nanostructures are particularly advantageous, promoting the exposure of more active sites in the electrolyte solution and thus accelerating H2 production and reducing the dark area. Compared to bulk nanomaterials, electrocatalysts with specific (e.g., 1D, 2D, and 3D) nanostructures feature more exposed active sites, thus presenting better performance due to the accelerated electrolyte transport and the release of the generated bubbles [231–235]. Consequently, the design of specific nanostructures for electrocatalytic performance optimization has attracted much attention. Sun et al. [236] reported FeP-based hollow 1D nanostructures with MOF templates as HER catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 11(a) , MIL-88B nanorods were solvothermally synthesized in the presence of two metal salts and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-BDC) and pyrolyzed in air to afford semi-hollow mixed metal oxides (CoFeO x ), which were then subjected to phosphorization to obtain completely hollow Co-Fe-P nanotubes. The Co-Fe-P nanotubes presented high HER performance over a wide pH range, featuring overpotentials of 86, 138, and 66 mV@10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, 1 M PBS, and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. The 1D morphology with internal voids has many merits for promoting electrocatalytic performance, e.g., high specific surface area, low density, and short charge and mass transport routes. Over the past decades, 2D electrocatalysts have attracted much attention owing to their tunable and uniformly exposed lattice planes, unique electronic states, fast mass transport, and high percentage of exposed active sites [14,237–240]. Zhou et al. [241] used a salt-templating strategy to synthesize various single-crystalline non-layered 2D metal phosphides, including Co2P, MoP2, Ni12P5, and WP2. SEM and TEM imaging confirmed that these species featured a 2D morphology with a flake area of >50 μm2 (Figs. 11(b) and (c)). In particular, Co2P with exposed (1(-)30) facets presented remarkable HER performance (41 mV@10 mA cm−2. Yang et al. [242] developed an ice-templating method to synthesize CoP aerogels comprising ultrathin (<1.5 nm) 2D CoP nanosheets and revealed their excellent HER performance over a wide pH range. Zhen et al. [243] prepared hollow FeP nanoparticles encapsulated in 2D carbon nanosheet frameworks (hollow FeP/C nanosheets) from Fe glycolate. As shown in Fig. 11(d), the precursor was pyrolyzed to afford Fe3O4 nanoparticles encapsulated in a carbon nanosheet framework, and the subsequent confined phosphorization with excess PH3 afforded hollow FeP nanoparticles because of the Kirkendall effect. The high surface area and abundantly porous hollow 2D nanostructure of this catalyst resulted in the exposure of numerous active sites to accelerate the electrocatalytic process. The in situ formed carbon matrix lowered the resistance, prevented the aggregation of FeP nanoparticles, and afforded 2D conductive networks. Moreover, FeP/C nanosheets easily formed a conductive film on glassy carbon electrodes, which accelerated electron and ion transport during the electrochemical process. Consequently, the obtained electrocatalyst presented remarkable HER activity (51.1 mV@10 mA cm−2 and 41.7 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4). Apart from 1D and 2D nanostructures, 3D ones also hold great promise for enhancing electrocatalytic performance through the increased exposure of active sites, acceleration of electrolyte transport, and promotion of gas release. Shen et al. [244] prepared a 3D Prussian blue analogue (PBA) with well-defined spatial organization from Ni(OH)2 as the precursor (NHPBA). Figs. 11(e)–(k) show that the smooth plates of pristine Ni(OH)2 were covered by small nanocubes, the amount of which significantly increased with increasing reaction time. As a result, the originally smooth Ni(OH)2 plates were completely converted into rough plates with nanocubes after 24 h. Moreover, the size of individual nanocubes increased from 30 to 200 nm as the reaction time increased from 0.5 to 24 h owing to the Ostwald ripening of PBA. Finally, the desired electrocatalyst was obtained by the phosphorization of NHPBA (NHPBAP) and exhibited excellent HER performance (70 mV@10 mA cm−2 and 266 mV@500 mA cm−2). This remarkable activity was attributed to the abundance of active sites due to the well-pertained nanostructure of PBA nanocubes and regular Ni(OH)2 arrays as well as to the reduced charge transfer resistance and the expedited release of H2 bubbles due to the 3D nanostructure. Choi et al. [245] developed a facile one-step electrodeposition strategy to prepare 3D porous Cu-Co-P x foams using in situ generated H2 bubbles as templates. The areal proportion of pores and the number of surface pores increased with increasing concentration of NaH2PO2 during electrodeposition because of the concomitant increase in the number of H2 bubbles. Moreover, the increased concentration of NaH2PO2 decreased the mass loading of the electrocatalyst owing to the vigorous HER, which consumed more electrons. Interestingly, the composition of Cu-Co-P x could be tuned by altering the concentration of NaH2PO2, as this change altered the reduction overpotentials of Cu and Co. The prepared electrocatalyst featured a large electrochemical surface area and a high areal proportion of pores, featuring a small overpotential of 138 mV@10 mA cm−2. In addition to electrocatalysts with different dimensions, those with core-shell nanostructures have also been extensively studied to regulate HER activity [246–251]. Wang et al. [252] explored a new approach to improve the electrocatalytic performance of FeP by constructing core-shell-structured Fe@FeP and revealed that metallic Fe incorporated into FeP changed the hydrogen adsorption energy to an optimal value. DFT calculations demonstrated that the hydrogen adsorption energy of Fe@FeP was lower than that of FeP and close to that of Pt (111). Moreover, the calculated ΔG H* of Fe@FeP equaled 0.03 eV (i.e., hydrogen adsorption was predicted to be essentially thermoneutral), demonstrating that the prepared electrocatalyst featured an optimal surface. Bader charge analysis suggested the transfer of ~1.1 electrons per slab unit from Fe to FeP upon interface formation, which was assumed to afford an optimal hydrogen adsorption energy. As a result, small overpotentials of 53 mV@10 mA cm−2 and 110 mV@100 mA cm−2 were obtained in acidic solution. Lu and co-authors [253] developed N-doped carbon-decorated CoP@FeCoP yolk-shelled micropolyhedra (CoP@FeCoP/NC YSMPs) via MOF formation followed by an anion-exchange reaction with [Fe(CN)6]3− and treatment with NaH2PO2·H2O (Fig. 12(a) ). The experimental results demonstrated that the yolk-shell structure exhibited large electrochemical and specific surface areas, which promoted electrocatalytic performance enhancement. Moreover, the yolk-shell structure not only reduced the aggregation of CoP and exposed more active sites, but also affected the electronic structure by promoting electron migration from the FeCoP/NC shell to the CoP/NC core. As a result, the above catalyst featured an overpotential of 141 mV@10 mA cm−2 in an alkaline medium. In addition to metal core-shell structures, those with heteroatom-doped carbon as a shell are also known [254,255]. Shao et al. [256] synthesized core-shell structures with noble metal phosphides as the core and N,P-co-doped carbon (MP x @NPGC) as the shell and probed their HER performances in acidic and alkaline electrolytes. The catalytic performances of MP x @NPGC followed the order of PtP2@NPGC < IrP2@NPGC < RuP2@NPGC < Pd5P2@NPGC <RhP2@NPGC in 0.5 M H2SO4 and Pd5P2@NPGC <IrP2@NPGC <PtP2@NPGC <RhP2@NPGC <RuP2@NPGC in 1 M KOH. The references (pure metal phosphides and physical mixtures of different metal phosphides with graphene) presented poorer activities than core-shell catalysts because of the strong effects of core–shell interactions on electrocatalytic performance. Wang et al. [261] prepared hierarchical NiCoP hollow nanoflowers with an ultrathin nanosheet assembly by the hydrothermal treatment of Ni-Co glycerate nanospheres followed by phosphorization. The hierarchical Ni-Co glycerate was prepared by exploiting the interactions of Ni2+ and Co2+ with glycerol during the solvothermal process and was subsequently hydrothermally treated at various temperatures (20–220 °C) to afford the Ni-Co precursor. As illustrated in Figs. 12(b)–(e), the Ni-Co glycerate exhibited a solid-sphere (Ni-CoG-N) morphology with a diameter of ~500 nm. After hydrothermal treatment at 80 °C (Ni-CoG-80), numerous nanosheets were formed on the surface of the solid spheres. Interestingly, a hollow structure covered with self-assembled nanosheets was obtained after the hydrothermal process at 150 °C (Ni-CoG-150) owing to the Kirkendall effect. However, when the temperature was increased to 220 °C, the nanospheres disappeared, and only nanosheets formed (Ni-CoG-220), as the nanospheres could not withstand the high-pressure conditions. Fig. 12(f) shows the evolution of nanostructure with increasing hydrothermal temperature, revealing the importance of the latter parameter for nanostructure tuning. The hollow nanostructure allowed the exposure of abundant active surface and affluent mass transport channels, and the synthesized electrocatalyst therefore exhibited small overpotentials of 97 and 127 mV@10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline media, respectively. Several mesoporous metal phosphides with microsphere morphology, including monometallic (FeP, CoP, Ni2P, and Cu3P), bimetallic (Co6Ni4P5), and trimetallic (Co4Ni3Cu2P10) phosphides, were prepared via an aerosol spray-based method followed by phosphorization [262]. In detail, metal oxide microspheres were generated by aerosol spraying using a spray system composed of a household ultrasonic humidifier, a tube furnace, and a sample collector. Then, metal phosphides were obtained by treating the collected metal oxide microspheres with phosphorus sources (Fig. 12(g)). Other specific morphologies have also been explored to enhance HER performance [263,264], which indicates that electrocatalyst nanostructure plays a significant role in activity tuning. 4.6 Design of bi- and polymetallic phosphides As discussed above, interfaces can be formed in bimetallic phosphides and play a significant role in promoting electrocatalytic performance. In addition to the interface effects, coupling effects, such as electronic interactions, also play a pivotal role in promoting catalytic activity [276,277]. In general, metal phosphides are doped with different heteroatoms, except P, to form the second phase. The electronegativity difference between P and the doped heteroatoms allows one to optimize the electrocatalytic performance. Moreover, metal phosphides can be doped with second or third metals to optimize the catalytic activity via reaction kinetics tuning. The principle of elemental doping is to choose elements different from those in metal phosphides while considering the dopant electronegativity, atomic radius, and cost. Thus, bi- and polymetallic phosphides have been explored to regulate HER performance. The effect of one plus one can be greater than two, even if the interactivity of the various metals is different. In addition, electrical conductivity can also be optimized to a certain extent. Bi- and polymetallic phosphides contain two or more phases. Suib and co-authors [278] fabricated bimetallic Ni2P and Cu3P phosphides on NiCuC foil (Ni2P-Cu3P@NiCuC) and tuned the content of Cu (0, 10 wt%, 20 wt%, 30 wt%, and 40 wt% Cu: NCP-0, NCP-1, NCP-2, NCP-3, and NCP-4, respectively) to regulate electrocatalytic activity. As illustrated in Fig. 13(a) , NCP-3 exhibited the best HER performance, featuring overpotentials of 78 mV@10 mA cm−2 and 190 mV@100 mA cm−2 (cf. NCP-0 (158 mV, 247 mV), NCP-1 (158 mV, 240 mV), NCP-2 (102 mV, 222 mV), Ni foam (222 mV, 307 mV), and NiCuC (199 mV, 305 mV)). This behavior indicated that electrocatalytic performance was closely correlated with the composition of the bimetallic phosphide. DFT calculations revealed that catalytic performance was mainly promoted by the electronic interaction between Ni2P and Cu3P and the effects of coupling on H binding energy. A similar phenomenon was observed by Kang et al. [279], who prepared CoP-Cu3P with different contents of CoP and revealed that this binary phosphide presented excellent electrocatalytic activity in acidic, basic, and neutral electrolytes owing to the synergistic effects between CoP and Cu3P and the unique nanostructure. Choi and co-authors [280] prepared a Fe x Ni2−x P alloy with an alterable composition and investigated the promotional effects of alloying on electrocatalytic performance. Among the investigated alloys, the best performance (163 mV@50 mA cm−2) was observed for Fe0.5Ni1.5P, whereas the corresponding values for Ni2P (170 mV), Fe1.0Ni1.0P (178 mV), Fe1.5Ni0.5P (214 mV) and Fe2P (217 mV) were higher (Fig. 13(b)). Moreover, among the tested samples, Fe0.5Ni1.5P also exhibited the highest exchange current density (j 0) of 0.37 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13(c)). The results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and X-ray absorption near edge structure spectroscopy demonstrated that compared to other samples, Fe0.5Ni1.5P featured the most electron-deficient P atoms. The results of extended X-ray absorption fine structure measurements proved that the minimal distortion of the M–M bond led to the electronic deficiency of P, thus demonstrating the effects of alloying on electrocatalytic performance. In addition to crystalline and non-precious metal phosphides, Liu and co-authors [281] synthesized bimetallic amorphous Ru-Fe phosphide nanoclusters (Ru x Fe y P-NCs) on graphitized carbon nanofibers (CNFs). Experimental results demonstrated that the co-existence of Ru and Fe plays a significant role in tuning the electrocatalytic performance, with the best HER performance in both acidic (66 mV@10 mA cm−2, 132 mV@100 mA cm−2) and alkaline (16 mV@10 mA cm−2, 111 mV@100 mA cm−2) electrolytes observed for ΔG H* (compared with FeP-NCs/CNF, Ru2FeP-NCs/CNF, and RuFe2P-NCs/CNF). This finding indicated that both the introduced Ru and the Ru/Fe molar ratio are the key factors for promoting electrocatalytic performance. Theoretical calculations demonstrate that the introduction of Ru into FeP can lower the energy barrier for the reaction between metal sites and H*. Moreover, all Ru x Fe y P-NCs/CNFs exhibited less negative ΔG H* than RuFe-NCs/CNF, i.e., the introduced P favored H2 generation (Fig. 13(d)). The Ru/Fe molar ratio also affected ΔG H*, in line with the experimental results. Zou et al. [282] systematically investigated the effects of the Mo/Co molar ratio on HER performance, showing that ΔG H* decreased with increasing Mo/Co molar ratio. Moreover, the H–P binding energy was highest for Mo x Co1−x P (011), as the substitution of Co atoms by Mo modified the electronic structure and thus enhanced electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 13(e)). However, the inherent lattice structure was damaged, which induced a transformation from a single-crystalline to a polycrystalline structure and increased electrical resistance. The above substitution had both negative and positive effects, and a good balance was therefore essential for electrocatalytic performance optimization. Guan et al. [283] synthesized trimetallic Fe-Co-Cu phosphides embedded in N-doped carbon graphene (FeCoCuP@NC). Compared to the related monometallic and bimetallic phosphides, FeCoCuP@NC exhibited higher HER performance in acidic media (80 mV@10 mA cm−2, Fig. 13(f)). A similar performance trend was also observed in alkaline electrolytes, indicating the effects of coupling between different metal phosphides. High-entropy alloys comprising several elements have recently attracted much attention owing to their superior hardness, high strength, easily tailored composition, and other advantages [284–288]. Mu and co-authors [289] synthesized high-entropy metal phosphides (HEMPs) comprising Co, Cr, Mn, Fe, and Ni using the eutectic solvent method and demonstrated that their HER performance was superior to that of the related monometallic metal phosphides. Thus, HEMPs comprising multiple elements and featuring specific nanostructures should be further explored. 4.7 Other strategies In addition to the above extensively investigated strategies, other methods such as heterojunction construction have been explored to optimize the HER performance of metal phosphides [303–305]. Heterojunctions not only provide a special electron transport path, but also accelerate charge transfer and provide electrons and vacancies to favor the HER. Therefore, we herein discuss the promotional role of a two-phase heterojunction on HER activity. Shao et al. [306] designed a two-phase (MoP2 and MoP) electrocatalyst with remarkable HER performance in neutral electrolytes. The MoP2 phase with high contrast between the electrostatic affinity of Mo δ+ to –OH and P δ− to –H accelerated the dissociation of H2O molecules, while MoP with optimally exposed Mo atoms provided active sites for Had recombination. Interestingly, the MoP700 catalyst exhibited the best HER performance in neutral (and not in acidic or basic) electrolytes, unlike MoP2, MoP, and Mo3P, for which the activity trend was acidic > acidic > basic (Fig. 14(a) ). Fig. 14(b) presents the mechanism proposed for MoP700 in a neutral electrolyte. In an alkaline electrolyte, the OH− ions from the electrolyte/H2O can either occupy the hydroxyl adsorption sites or prevent the desorption of OHad from the catalytically active sites for H2O chemisorption/dissociation on MoP700, which results in an insufficient release of OHad and catalyst deactivation. Similar effects were also observed in acidic media owing to the excess of H+ on the prepared electrocatalysts. However, H+/OH− cannot affect the electrocatalytic activity in neutral electrolytes, in which case the activity was in the order of MoP700 > MoP > MoP2, indicating that the surface MoP2/MoP can guarantee fast H2O dissociation to afford high electrocatalytic performance in neutral media (196 mV@10 mA cm−2). During the electrocatalytic HER, H2 bubbles are rapidly generated on the contact surface between the catalyst and the electrolyte, which hinders liquid mass transport, decelerates electron transfer, and decreases the number of exposed active sites, thereby decreasing electrocatalytic performance. Surface properties also play a pivotal role in regulating electrocatalytic activity. Yu et al. [307] prepared Ni2P nanoarrays on commercial Ni foam (Ni2P/NF) with unique superaerophobic properties to enable the timely release of H2 bubbles at large current densities. As shown in Fig. 14(c), the H2 bubbles were readily pinned on the NF surface but were rapidly released from the Ni2P/NF surface. The schematic illustration reveals that the formed H2 bubbles adhered to the surface of bare NF and thus reduced the contact interface between the electrolyte and the solid, which resulted in poor catalytic activity. For Ni2P/NF, the superaerophobic properties guaranteed the timely release of the formed bubbles to expose the active sites, which resulted in remarkable electrocatalytic performance and excellent stability at high current density. Yin and co-authors [308] created CoP species in Co-MOF (CoP/Co-MOF) via the hydrothermal deposition of Co(OH)F on carbon fiber paper (CF) followed by a reaction with imidazole vapor and partial phosphorization using sodium hypophosphite (Fig. 14(d)). The specific porous nanostructure of Co-MOF exposed more active sites and accelerated the release of the generated gas. Moreover, DFT calculations showed that electron transfer from CoP to Co-MOF through N–P and N–Co bonds resulted in optimal ΔG H2O and ΔG H*. Consequently, CoP/Co-MOF exhibited remarkable HER performance in neutral, basic, and acidic electrolytes (49, 34, and 27 mV@10 mA cm−2, respectively). For metal phosphides, the content of P affects the extent of electron delocalization originating from the M-P donor-acceptor interaction and thus affects the interaction between phosphides and H+ in acidic media [309]. It is widely accepted that higher P contents result in optimal hydrogen adsorption energy and accelerate the reaction kinetics. Geyer and co-authors [310] synthesized P-rich colloidal CoP2 nanocrystals (NCs) with an average size of 18 ± 2 nm. As illustrated in Fig. 14(e), CoP2 NCs exhibited better HER performance (39 mV@10 mA cm−2, 32 mV dec−1) than CoP NCs (52 mV@10 mA cm−2) and Co2P NCs (65 mV@10 mA cm−2). Among the other strategies of HER performance enhancement, one can mention the construction of single-crystalline structures to expose specific facets [304,311]. 5 Conclusions and perspectives This review summarizes the recent developments in metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts. The corresponding synthetic methods are classified according to the phosphorization strategy (post-treatment, in situ generation, and electrodeposition), and the approaches used to regulate electrocatalytic performance are classified into those relying on elemental doping, interface engineering, vacancy engineering, use of specific supports, and construction of specific nanostructures. The enhancement of electrocatalytic activity after processing by the above methods is ascribed to the optimization of electronic structure, reaction kinetics, active site exposure, and mass/electron transfer. Finally, the key issues and countermeasures are discussed to further improve the performance of metal phosphides as HER catalysts. Despite the efforts made to simplify the synthesis of metal phosphides and elevate their HER performance, their future development to achieve practical H2 production faces several challenges, which (together with the related perspectives) are summarized below. (1) The development of facile, low-toxic, and energy-conserving synthetic approaches. As discussed above, metal phosphides are mainly prepared via three methods (among which the post-treatment approach is the most popular one) that employ toxic chemicals and complicated procedures. Electrodeposition is a facile and low-toxicity method of synthesizing metal phosphides; however, the thus generated monotonous nanostructures limit the number of exposed active sites. Thus, it is important to exploit novel and facile methods to synthesize metal phosphides with optimal nanostructures to promote electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. (2) The exploration of novel and more effective metal phosphides as HER catalysts. At present, research on metal phosphides mainly focuses on transition metal phosphides. However, their electrocatalytic performance is still lower than that of noble metals. Therefore, there is an urgent need to explore novel metal phosphides with higher catalytic performance. For instance, the combination of transition metals with trace precious metals is a promising way of electrocatalytic activity enhancement. (3) The development of more kinds of supports for metal phosphides. As mentioned above, supports play a pivotal role in tuning the catalytic performance of metal phosphides owing to synergistic interactions. Therefore, it is worthwhile to exploit other (non-carbon) matrices such as metal nitrides and metal carbides. The electronic interactions, formation of interfaces, and the generation of abundant channels can optimize the adsorption/desorption of intermediates and accelerate mass/electron transport. Thus, the development of matrices with specific nanostructures or various heteroatoms is necessary to optimize the catalytic performance. (4) The design of metal phosphides with various kinds of vacancies. The generated vacancies allow one to tune the electronic structure, regulate the active sites, and lower the resistance of nanomaterials. However, the related research mainly focuses on anionic vacancies owing to the fact that they are easier to form than cationic vacancies. However, cationic vacancies also play a significant role in promoting electrocatalytic performance. Therefore, the development of metal phosphides with one or more types of ionic vacancies is a promising strategy of promoting catalytic activity. (5) In situ spectroscopic surface analysis of electrode evolution during the HER. The electrocatalytic HER is a dynamic reaction involving H2 bubble generation and reduction. Thus, observations of nanostructure evolution and intermediate adsorption/desorption during the electrocatalytic process allow one to guide the design of high-performance electrocatalysts. To date, various in situ characterization methods such as in situ Raman and in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy have been applied to observe these dynamic changes. (6) Long-term preservation of metal phosphide activity. The loss of P (particularly in alkaline solutions) seriously affects the activity of metal phosphides and complicates its long-term preservation. Therefore, the prevention of this loss is an important challenge to be addressed in the future. The other challenges to consider are the easy oxidation of phosphides in air and their reduced HER activity due to the presence of oxygen atoms. Therefore, the effect of oxygen atoms on the HER activity of metal phosphides should be considered in future research. References 1 L. Huang M. Wei S. Zaman A. Ali B.Y. Xia Chem. Eng. Lei Wang (College of Environment and Safety Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology) was invited as a young member of 6th Editorial Board (2020–2024) of Chin. J Catal. in 2020. Professor Lei Wang received his Ph.D degree in 2006 from Jilin University. Afterward, he joined the faculty of Qingdao University of Science and Technology, where he was the deputy director of Key Laboratory of Eco-Chemical Engineering, and he is now the director of College of Environment and Safety Engineering. From 2008 to 2010, he worked as a postdoctoral fellow in the State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University. His research interests currently focus on the design and synthesis of porous MOFs materials and functional inorganic materials, as well as their applications in gas separation, photocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, etc. Professor Lei Wang has published more than 200 papers, including Nat. Commun., Adv. Energy Mater., Adv. Funct. Mater., etc.

coredata.dc:description: Among the sustainable energy sources, hydrogen is the one most promising for alleviating the pollution issues related to the usage of conventional fuels, as it can be produced in an efficient and eco-friendly way via electrocatalytic water splitting. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, a half-reaction of water splitting) plays a pivotal role in decreasing the price and increasing the catalytic efficiency of hydrogen production and is efficiently promoted by metal phosphides in different electrolytes. Herein, we summarize the recent advances in the development of metal phosphides as HER electrocatalysts, focus on their synthesis (post-treatment, in situ generation, and electrodeposition methods) and the enhancement of their electrocatalytic activity (via elemental doping, interface and vacancy engineering, construction of specific supports and nanostructures, and the design of bi- or polymetallic phosphides), and highlight the crucial issues and challenges of future development.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Strategies on improving the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution performances of metal phosphides
